description:
It's been a week of turbulence for Nigeria's economy. Tensions escalated after the presidential elections planned for this weekend were postponed for six weeks due to security concerns. Already the volatile oil price has pushed the currency, the naira, lower. But this week it crashed through the key level of 200 to the dollar, prompting the central bank to start frantically buying the currency to try and pop it up. The country's credit worthiness also took a knock after the ratings agency Standard & Poor gave the economy a negative outlook. Yesterday the head of Nigeria's central bank said there was no need to panic and urged investors to stay calm. Well I spoke to the BBC's Lerato Mbele in Lagos and she told me there was some optimism now that the currency stability will return.

Well business leaders are still optimistic that this isn't the worst that can happen to Nigeria. They do want to see currency stability. They do want to see the naira stay stable because as you know Nigeria operates on a fixed exchange rate. The central bank, as you say, is coming out to defend the naira. But for them it's a dire situation because at the end of the day they've had to buy so many US dollars that they're depleting foreign reserves. But Tony O. Elumelu was the chief executive of Nigeria's largest bank UBA for 20 years. He's now become one of the richest bankers in the country and he says the worst has not yet come.
